Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Creating a TTP Ecosystem Discovery and Support Resource for Cybersecurity Technology Transfer to Practice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2011 Federal Cybersecurity Research and Development Plan cites "Accelerating Transition to Practice (TTP)" as one of five strategic objectives in the Cyber Security and Information Assurance (CSIA) Program Component Area. TTP remains a strategic objective of Agencies which fund cybersecurity research, including NSF. However, the NSF cybersecurity portfolio contains only a small amount of security research that has been transitioned into operational activities. The Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) of the White House defines transition to practice as research that "creates measurable improvements in the cybersecurity landscape". Although NSF encourages security researchers with promising applied research projects to submit TTP (Transition to Practice) projects, a very low percentage of researchers take advantage of this opportunity. This EAGER will serve as an outreach vehicle to cybersecurity Principal Investigators (PIs), informing them of the advantages of engaging in a TTP and instructing them on the differences between a traditional research proposal and a TTP-focused one. The PI's will conduct workshops at three PI meetings for NSF programs - Cybersecurity Innovation for Cyberinfrastructure (CICI), Campus Cyberinfrastructure (CC*) and Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) as well as at several academic conferences, including USENIX Security and Security and Privacy (S&P) among others.

In 2015, NSF sponsored two workshops which brought together key stakeholders to provide insights on how to improve the TTP process and encourage more TTP submissions. An important outcome of that workshop was the identification of specific barriers to TTP. In order to keep momentum going from these workshops, this follow-on project identifies specific ways in which PI's can overcome these barriers as they consider how to address TTP. The project establishes workshops for PI's to write more focused proposals, and provides opportunities for the PI's to engage with the NSF-funded cybersecurity community to foster more transition of cybersecurity research into the hands of the operational Information Technology Community. The expected outcome is that NSF expands the impact of the cybersecurity research it funds by producing more TTP results in the near to mid-term in order to make cyberspace safer.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
I. Nature of Project

This project targeted a stated NSF priority: facilitating the transfer of funded research to actual use or commercialization, in oirder to achieve a positive impact on society. Previously, barriers and challenges to the transition to practice (TTP) of cybersecurity technology were identified. Then, key features of a NSF ecosystem for governmental and academic researchers in cybersecurity were identified and prioritized.

II. Goals of Project & Key Activities

Armed with data about what the relevant customer segments found to be obstacles and specific needs, this project established goals deemed critical to expand and increase the impact of cybersecurity research by facilitating TTP. A list of key activities was created in order to accomplish these goals: (1) TTP education, outreach and recruitment; (2) identification of prospective TTP investigators; (3) training in TTP for prospective TTP investigators; (4) recruitment of qualified TTP cybersecurity mentors ; (5) organization of potential mentors in a manner to provide assistance; and (6) development of certain best practices in TTP.

III. Project Deliverables 

From this list of key activities, the project then created programmatic deliverables that provided those value propositions (i.e., benefits) considered important by prospective TTP investigators.  In turn, these deliverables facilitated TTP by helping eliminate obstacles and barriers and by providing needed resources. Those deliverables included: (1) development of a TTP module (mini-curriculum) presentation incorporating relevant I-Corps and Lean Launch principles; (2) creation of a master list of then prospective TTP investigators; (3) organization and implementation of workshops and presentations to prospective TTP investigators; (4) identification and recruitment of qualified (e.g., previously successful) TTP researchers as potential mentors; (5) establishment of a master TTP mentoring group; and (6) creation of a ”Best TTP Practices” repository following surveys and interviews of TTP mentors.

 IV. Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of this project was significant in the creation of specific benefits and resources to researchers that helped eliminate the barriers and obstacles to TTP previously identified by them. Moreover, the project incorporated I-Corps principles in presentations and workshops to help focus research that in turn assisted TTP in targeting applications and uses identified as critical and feasible. In short, TTP should be easier, faster and more responsive to real world needs in cybersecurity because: (1) data indicating specific needs was incorporated into training, (2) access to successful TTP researchers available as mentors was provided, and (3) a list of best practices was implemented and made available.

 V. Broader Impacts

This project had broad impact. The project scope spanned government agencies and multiple companies in the private sector interested in cybersecurity. The training and workshops affected cybersecurity researchers across the United States. The creation of a mentoring group not only provided access to experts, but it facilitated among the mentors an interest and willingness to provide free assistance to propective TTP researchers. The Best Practices repository will provide ongoing assistance to prospective TTP researchers. Finally, the project created greater interest and motivation among cybersecurity researchers to pursue TTP funding from NSF.

 


Last Modified: 10/16/2019
Modified by: Michael Chambers
